captions.text:
How to Hand Train a Bird. You may not be able
to get your parakeet to balance a ball on

his beak, but every hook-billed species -- from
parakeets to cockatoos -- can be trained to

step onto your finger when you tell him to.
You will need Hook-billed species Birdcage

Perch Hand Patience and t-stand (optional)
(optional) (optional). Step 1. Don’t try

to take your bird out of his cage unless his
wings have been clipped. Step 2. To get your

bird not to flip out when you put your hand
into his cage, several times a day insert

your hand into the cage and wave it slowly
in the bird’s direction. Repeat this daily

until the bird gets used to it. Try holding
a bird treat when you put your hand into the

cage. Once you can get your bird to eat from
your hand, you’re well on the way toward

establishing “hand trust.” Step 3. For
the next two weeks, insert your hand into

the cage several times a day--but this time,
hold a perch or stick in your hand. Your goal:

getting the bird to step onto the perch. Step
4. When the bird gets used to the perch in

your hand, start getting him to step onto
it. Hold it at a right angle to the bird’s

body and gently nudge him in the chest. This
will trigger his “step up” reflex. Always

say “Up, up” or “Step up” when you
nudge the bird with the perch. Give him lots

of praise when he steps onto it. He’s making
progress! Step 5. When the bird is comfortable

standing on a hand-held perch, you can start
training him to stand on your hand alone.

During each training session, move your hand
farther down the perch -- and closer to the

bird. Step 6. After a few days, your bird
should assume that a perch comes with a hand

attached--so now it’s time to up the ante
once again. What’s next? That’s right:

your hand without the perch. Step 7. Moving
slowly and smoothly and repeating the “Up,

up” command, nudge the bird in the chest
until he has no choice but to step onto your

pointer finger to steady himself. Step 8.
Repeat this procedure until the bird has no

problem stepping onto your finger and perching
there. Step 9. Now you and your feathered

friend can begin working outside the cage.
With the bird perched on your finger, slowly

and smoothly bring him out through the cage
door. If you have a large bird, a T-stand

will be a helpful training tool when working
outside the cage. Practice putting the bird

onto the T-stand and taking him off again.
Step 10. Practice the “Up, up” command

diligently until the bird knows that he should
always step onto your “finger perch” when

you say so. If the bird gets startled and
flutters off your hand, calmly follow him

to where he lands and nudge him, saying “Up,
up.” Usually, he’ll step right back onto

your finger. Step 11. Encourage your friends
and relatives to work with your bird as much

as possible. The tamer a bird becomes, the
happier his relationship with his human flock

will be. Did you know Birds in the parrot
family have two toes facing forward and two

facing backward, to help them hold onto things
while they’re climbing.

title: How to Hand Train a Bird

comments.author: Rakesh Jaiswal

comments.text:
Each bird is different. They have different personalities. I had mine for 
nearly 2 weeks. He does not have his wings clipped. He just has so much fun 
flying around (once he even landed on my back, he sometimes tries flying 
onto my head - I won't take it as an insult that my head looks like a 
bird's nest). After a few days, he already let me carry him back to his 
cage using a stand he was used to (it's actually a small, flat cat 
scratching post - the surface is resistant, but cozy like a nest, and he 
loves taking naps on it). Once he got sleepy (lazy more like), I went to 
him and used the stand, and he immediately got onto it. He is not used to 
human hands yet. He won't eat out of the hand, he doesn't want pets. I also 
have no treats for him yet (they are not sold around here, so I'll have to 
make some, once I learn how). So if you want to carry your bird around, 
right from the beginning, first place some flat surface, or a longer perch, 
next to his cage that he can get onto. Once he gets comfortable with it, 
try getting him to stand on it. You should NEVER wave it next to his head, 
just simply insert it below him, motioning upward to his feet. Use any 
queue word you like. Or don't. I don't yet. I simply gesture to him. He 
doesn't really listen to words yet. But he understands gestures.﻿
comments.author: Anomaly Sg

them tamed, and can hold them and have them with me. However, I can't 
always get them to step up from inside the cage. I will be starting to 
teach them how these next few weeks- thanks for the tips! Wish me luck!﻿

comments.author: Veronica Szczepanik

comments.text:
+Veronica Szczepanik You don't need to clip your bird's wings. Mine is so 
happy flying around the house. You can keep your bird fully flighted as 
well, IF your house is safe for it to fly around. Cover windows with 
curtains, mirrors too. Close the toilet lid (it might fall in it and 
drown). If you let it in the kitchen make sure there's nothing that it can 
get hurt in (a pot of boiling water might look like a nice bath for it, 
fumes coming from non-stick pans, oil can get on its wings and then it 
won't be able to keep its body temperature at a proper level, etc). Make 
sure not to have any poisonous plants in the house. See what plants and 
fruits (avocado) are poisonous for Cockatiels. Make sure it has "perches" 
(furniture) that it can easily land on. So it has where to fly, otherwise 
it will hit the wall and probably crack its beak. Keep in mind Cockatiels 
are not vertical fliers. It won't be able to ascend or descend abruptly in 
a short distance.

would probably kill the bird. There's a few guides online, but you're

large amount of lift off the ground.

comments.text:
Well it is very simple, but, with most birds you will have to be upmost 
patient. 
1. Dont smack or tap the bird at all, it will only seem threatened and 
scared by it.
2. Act as if it isnt hurting and dont give it up and put the bird back into 
its cage. 
3. And repeat the steps on this video.

comments.author: Julie Arnold

comments.text:
After we got new furniture we stopped letting our birds out. One was old, 
and died a few years later, but the other was in the cage for like 6 years. 
My parents and I felt really bad about leaving it in there for so long, and 
I constantly asked to let her out, but we never could because our new dogs 
would kill them or they would shit all over our new furniture. A couple 
months ago, I convinced my dad to let me take her out. She was terrified, 
we had to end up cornering her and pushing her out of the cage where she 
landed on the floor, then she would go on our hand. She didn't want to be 
pet, and everytime you tried to get her onto your hand she would bite you. 
A few days later, she began to open up and lightly wanted to be pet. About 
2 or 3 weeks later, I would stick my hand in her cage and she started to 
hesitantly come on it, without throwing a bf (bird fit). Now she loves to 
be pet, she's always out of her cage (mostly by me, no one else really 
takes her out) and she willingly climbs onto my hands, and sometimes 
doesn't want to go back into her cage. She's opened up so much, it's 
amazing.﻿

comments.text:
please to anyone watching this. do not clip your birds wings. that is just 
a laziness factor for people trying to tame a bird. When you clip a bird it 
loses it's sense of independence which also hurts it's trust in you. if you 
work with them they will eventually not fly away. clipping it's wing is 
just people being lazy and trying to skip the "trust" stage. simply having 
patience is 100x more effective than removing a birds ability to feel 
safe. ﻿

comments.author: Stack 'N Flip

comments.text:
You're right, I didn't clip my birds wings. People say that your bird will 
die. That's not true. Usually, bird will fly into walls and stuff, then 
eventually learn how to fly. If you have a small cage in which they can't 
fly, of course they will get hurt. That's like living in a household and 
never being able to talk and then someone telling you to talk. My bird is 
able to fly around safely, because she has a big enough cage that keeps her 
flying and us big enough for her to fly. Please do your research. Oh and 
someone said they will fly into ceiling fans? Why would you 1: have a 
ceiling fan going even if your bird is just in the cage 2: why is the door 
open so your bird can get hurt by the ceiling fan?
comments.author: agworldoflove

comments.text:
Of course you do, and out of the 65+ birds I've dealt with over the years 
most do very well at it, clearly some don't, and this was a bird I had free 
flighted in that same room for four years, how much more could I train her? 
Birds weren't born to fly in tiny rooms, they were born to fly miles every 
day in search of food sources, a room indoors isn't even close. 

I cover all windows and mirrors which works for the lighter birds but not 
the big heavy birds, I can't pad every single wall too, it just isn't 
possible. It can happen so easily and quickly, the amount of rescues and 
trainers I deal with that have had flight related injuries is unreal, cut 
and bruised ceres, broken beaks, broken necks, broken wings, not worth it. 
I'm quite happy to keep a bird free flighted wherever possible, like the 
lighter birds. Like I say I take my birds out with me, and although they 
are clipped they can still fly and keep a fairly good height, clipping a 
bird so badly it can't even catch itself when it falls is worse than 
leaving it free flighted, at least free flighted they can catch themselves 
if they fall, but clipping the ends of the first four primaries just stops 
them picking up speed, it doesn't stop them flying completely, that is 
cruel I agree and dangerous.

I just know that once you have a bird you love that much die in your arms, 
and you have that pure terror and dread running through the pit of your 
stomach and spend days crying your eyes out like the world has ended, you 
would do anything in your power to prevent it happening again.
comments.author: darkladymiyu

comments.text: +darkladymiyu that's why u get them used to flying in a small room -_-
comments.author: Bowie The bird

comments.text: nope
comments.author: SuperApplepie7

comments.text:
I had a fully flighted bird ram into a window at full speed and die 
painfully over the course of about 5-10 minutes, even with a net curtain 
over the window, I was completely sick to my stomach over it. My smaller 
birds....the budgies....are fully flighted, as they bounce off the net 
curtains and other covers on windows and mirrors, the bigger birds don't, 
I'm not losing another one to a broken neck, and if the choice is clip them 
and allow them to fly slower and lower around the house clipped (clipping 
doesn't remove ability to fly as that is also dangerous when the bird 
plummets straight onto their keel bone), or have to keep them in their cage 
all the time to keep them safe in case they break their neck, I'd rather 
clip them and let them be free around the house. I also take my larger 
birds out with me in harnesses, and if the harness fails for some reason 
I'm not risking them flying off and being eaten by a hawk.

When you buy a larger bird and bond to it, they become your family, not 
just a pet or companion, and there is nothing worse than the soul 
destroying event of losing a pet you love so much to terrible injuries when 
it could so easily have been prevented by clipping. I've seen bad clips 
where a lot more than the first primaries were taken and these should never 
happen. I certainly prefer to keep a bird fully flighted where it is safe 
to do so as they do enjoy flying so much, but I will never forgive myself 
for allowing my bird to die through being so irresponsible, you don't think 
it will happen, you don't think clipping birds is right so you don't clip, 
then you watch your bird die a terrible painful death through your actions 
and you soon change your mind I can tell you, never again!
